Empty Product
In a monoid, the empty product is defined as the unit element, i.e., $\prod_{i=1}^{0} a_{i} := e$, where $e$ is the unit element.
Order of a group
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
Division Ring
A ring R is called a division ring or a skew field if R is not the zero ring and every nonzero element of R is a unit (R* = R - {0}).
Intersection of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Factorial ring/unique factorization domain

An integral domain $R$ satisfying the conditions that every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ can be uniquely written, up to associatedness and order, as a product of irreducible elements, and every element $a \in R-\left(R^{*} \cup\{0\}\right)$ is a product of prime elements. An element of a unique factorization domain is irreducible if and only if it is prime.
Finitely generated module
An A-module M is said to be finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators. It is also referred to as a finite A-module.
Rank of an A-module
The rank of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers n such that there exists a linearly independent system of elements x_1, ..., x_n in M.
Field Extension

A pair of fields $K \subset L$, where $K$ is a subfield of $L$, is called a field extension. $L$ is a field extending $K$ or an extension field of $K$, or simply that $L$ is a "field extension" of $K$.
Prime Subfield of a Finite Field
The prime subfield of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is the smallest subfield contained within $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$, where $p=\operatorname{char} \\[\mathbb{F}\]>0$.
Solvable group

A group $G$ is called solvable if there exists a chain of subgroups $G_{0} \\supsetneq G_{1} \\supsetneq \\ldots \\supsetneq G_{r}=\\{1\\}$ such that each $G_{i+1}$ is a normal subgroup of $G_{i}$ and the residue class group $G_{i} / G_{i+1}$ is abelian.
Normalizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
